what: 1.3 Start from the one-step function: gdm (Highly Recommended)
title: Optimal Parameters-based Geographical Detectors (OPGD) Model for Spatial Heterogeneity Analysis and Factor Exploration
text: pacakge provides one-step function performing optimal discretization geographical detectors time. output contains data visualization results.
code: ## install and library the pacakge install.packages("GD") library("GD")  ## Example 1 ## NDVI: ndvi_40 ## set optional parameters of optimal discretization ## optional methods: equal, natural, quantile, geometric, sd and manual discmethod <- c("equal","natural","quantile") discitv <- c(4:6) ## "gdm" function ## In this case, Climatezone and Mining are categorical variables, ## and Tempchange and GDP are continuous variables. ndvigdm <- gdm(NDVIchange ~ Climatezone + Mining + Tempchange + GDP,                continuous_variable = c("Tempchange", "GDP"),                data = ndvi_40,                discmethod = discmethod, discitv = discitv) # ~3s ndvigdm plot(ndvigdm)  ## Example 2 ## H1N1: h1n1_100 ## set optional parameters of optimal discretization discmethod <- c("equal","natural","quantile","geometric","sd") discitv <- c(3:7) continuous_variable <- colnames(h1n1_100)[-c(1,11)] ## "gdm" function h1n1gdm <- gdm(H1N1 ~ .,                continuous_variable = continuous_variable,                data = h1n1_100,                discmethod = discmethod, discitv = discitv) h1n1gdm plot(h1n1gdm)

title: Optimal Parameters-based Geographical Detectors (OPGD) Model for Spatial Heterogeneity Analysis and Factor Exploration
text: Spatial stratified heterogeneity can measured using geographical detectors (Wang et al. 2010, Wang et al. 2016). Power determinants computed using \(Q\)-statistic: \[Q=1-\displaystyle \frac{\sum_{j=1}^{M} N_{j} \sigma_{j}^2}{N \sigma^2} \] \(N\) \(\sigma^2\) number population variance observations within whole study area, \(N_{j}\) \(\sigma_{j}^2\) number population variance observations within \(j\) th (\(j\)=1,…,\(M\)) sub-region explanatory variable. Please note R environment, sd var functions used computing sample standard deviation sample variance. sample variance used computation, equation \(Q\)-statistic can converted : \[Q=1-\displaystyle \frac{\sum_{j=1}^{M} (N_{j}-1) s_{j}^2}{(N-1) s^2} \] \(s^2\) \(s_{j}^2\) sample variance observations whole study area \(j\) th sub-region. information can found manual GD package. applications geographical detectors listed Geodetector website.

title: Optimal Parameters-based Geographical Detectors (OPGD) Model for Spatial Heterogeneity Analysis and Factor Exploration

GD package provides two options: discretization given parameters, including discretization methods numbers intervals, optimal discretization series optional parameter combinations. Dataset ndvi_40 used example explanation.

title: Optimal Parameters-based Geographical Detectors (OPGD) Model for Spatial Heterogeneity Analysis and Factor Exploration
text: GD package provides two options geographical detectors modelling: four functions performed step step: gd factor detector, riskmean gdrisk risk detector, gdinteract interaction detector gdeco ecological detector; optimal discretization geographical detectors performed using one-step function gdm.

title: Optimal Parameters-based Geographical Detectors (OPGD) Model for Spatial Heterogeneity Analysis and Factor Exploration
code: ## a categorical explanatory variable g1 <- gd(NDVIchange ~ Climatezone, data = ndvi_40) g1  ## multiple categorical explanatory variables g2 <- gd(NDVIchange ~ ., data = ndvi_40[,1:3]) g2 plot(g2)  ## multiple variables including continuous variables discmethod <- c("equal","natural","quantile","geometric","sd") discitv <- c(3:7) data.ndvi <- ndvi_40  data.continuous <- data.ndvi[, c(1, 4:7)] odc1 <- optidisc(NDVIchange ~ ., data = data.continuous, discmethod, discitv) # ~14s data.continuous <- do.call(cbind, lapply(1:4, function(x)   data.frame(cut(data.continuous[, -1][, x], unique(odc1[[x]]$itv), include.lowest = TRUE))))     # add stratified data to explanatory variables data.ndvi[, 4:7] <- data.continuous  g3 <- gd(NDVIchange ~ ., data = data.ndvi) g3 plot(g3)
